title: Two vulnerabilities in the ssl module
vulnerability_information:
I found two vulnerabilities in python's ssl module. 

The first is a Py_XDECREF call on an object which isn't owned, leading to use-after-free and/or double free scenarios.
The second vulnerability is an uninitialized variable use. 
  
I described both issues in detail in a mail to the PSRT. The mail and fix for both issues is here:

https://bugs.python.org/issue27773
vulnerability_information_html:
I found two vulnerabilities in python's ssl module.

The first is a Py_XDECREF call on an object which isn't owned, leading to use-after-free and/or double free scenarios.
The second vulnerability is an uninitialized variable use.

I described both issues in detail in a mail to the PSRT. The mail and fix for both issues is here:

https://bugs.python.org/issue27773

activities.message: Hey @tehybel - the maintainers flagged this as a crash rather than a security issue. We haven't done a deeper analysis, but could you provide us with your interpretation of the bug's exploitability and impact?
activities.markdown_message: Hey @tehybel - the maintainers flagged this as a crash rather than a security issue. We haven't done a deeper analysis, but could you provide us with your interpretation of the bug's exploitability and impact?

activities.message:
Hi @arice, thanks for looking into this and for the bounties!

The python developers tend to tag this type of issue as a crash. I do not know why they prefer this.

I clicked three recent bugs which others reported (and got rewarded for) and all three were also tagged as crashes: 
https://hackerone.com/reports/129771
https://hackerone.com/reports/104033
https://hackerone.com/reports/104032

So I don't think the tag means much, it seems more like a default to me.

About the concrete issue I reported: It's a use-after-free and my PoC shows that a variable can be fully controlled. So my interpretation is that it's very likely exploitable. 

The impact is less clear; if an attacker can make the call to PyWeakref_NewRef in newPySSLSocket fail for any reason, the use-after-free occurs. I do not know which applications expose newPySSLSocket to an attacker with sufficient control.

activities.message: I forgot to mention that the title here says "two vulnerabilities" -- but the second one is unlikely to have any impact as it can't be reliably triggered by an attacker. I described that in more detail in the link I sent you. Therefore feel free to ignore the second issue.
